presidential-range.description: High alpine ridges with volatile weather; many hikers rehearse bailout options for Washington–Jefferson–Adams days.
presidential-range.extendedDescription: The Presidential Range forms the highest and most rugged spine of New Hampshire’s White Mountains, with nine NH48 summits—Mount Washington, Adams, Jefferson, Monroe, Madison, Eisenhower, Pierce, Jackson and Isolation—linked by an exposed alpine crest. The traverse is famous for severe winds and rapidly changing weather; many hikers attempt it in summer with careful bailout plans. Views are panoramic from treeless summits, and the range hosts the Mount Washington Observatory along with historic huts such as Madison and Lakes of the Clouds. Winter ascents demand mountaineering skill and full winter gear.
presidential-range.character: Alpine ridges with rocky trails, extensive above‑treeline exposure and volatile mountain weather.

seasonalConsiderations.summer: Plan for fast-moving storms and strong winds; start early for long traverses.
seasonalConsiderations.winter: Full winter mountaineering gear required; expect whiteout conditions and icy cairn-hopping.

The traverse is famous for severe winds and rapidly changing weather; many hikers attempt it in summer with careful bailout plans. Views are panoramic from treeless summits, and the range hosts the Mount Washington Observatory along with historic huts such as Madison and Lakes of the Clouds. Winter ascents demand mountaineering skill and full winter gear.

franconia-range.description: Iconic ridge walks featuring Lafayette, Lincoln, Liberty, Flume, and Garfield. Check route guides for conditions.
franconia-range.extendedDescription: The Franconia Range forms a dramatic ridge along Franconia Notch, culminating in Mount Lafayette and Mount Lincoln. The classic Franconia Ridge Loop links Flume, Liberty, Lincoln and Lafayette across an open alpine crest, offering some of the most spectacular ridge walking in the Northeast. Mount Garfield rises just to the north with panoramic views over the Pemigewasset Wilderness. Trails are steep and rocky but reward hikers with 360-degree vistas; winter conditions can be harsh and require traction.
franconia-range.character: Open ridge walking with steep ascents and sweeping views over Franconia Notch and the Pemigewasset Wilderness.

seasonalConsiderations.summer: Start early to avoid crowds and afternoon thunderstorms; sun and wind exposure is constant on the ridge.
seasonalConsiderations.winter: Trailheads may be icy and ridgeline winds are severe; carry microspikes or crampons and plan for short daylight.

kinsman-range.description: Moosilauke’s bald dome plus Cannon/Kinsman ledges overlooking Franconia Notch—expect changing footing and wind.
kinsman-range.extendedDescription: The Kinsman Range spans the western edge of the White Mountains and includes the dome of Mount Moosilauke, Cannon Mountain and the twin summits of North and South Kinsman. Moosilauke’s treeless summit offers wide views across the Connecticut River Valley, while Cannon and the Kinsmans rise above Franconia Notch with rugged ledges and alpine bogs. The range features a mix of moderate to steep climbs, and moose sightings are not uncommon along the forested approaches. Trail conditions vary with season; winter ascents demand traction and preparation for strong winds on exposed summits.
kinsman-range.character: Combination of open summit domes and cliffy ledges with moderate to rugged trails and changing weather.

seasonalConsiderations.summer: Trailheads off Franconia Notch and Ravine Lodge are busy; carry extra water for dry ridges.
seasonalConsiderations.winter: Expect wind on Moosilauke’s dome and icy ledges on Cannon and the Kinsmans; use traction devices and watch for closed roads.

carter-moriah-range.description: Forest duff, ledgy steps, and hut-to-hut options linking the Carters and Wildcats; exposure shifts with weather.
carter-moriah-range.extendedDescription: Forming the eastern wall of Pinkham Notch, the Carter-Moriah Range includes Carter Dome, Middle Carter, South Carter, Mount Moriah and the Wildcat peaks (A and D). Trails climb through spruce–fir forests to rocky ledges with views toward Mount Washington and the Presidential Range. Many hikers traverse the range via the Appalachian Trail, linking Carter Notch, Carter Dome and the Wildcats with hut stays at Carter Notch and the AMC Hut at Pinkham Notch. Weather can shift quickly along the ridge, making exposed ledges windy and slippery; winter ascents require traction and awareness of ice.
carter-moriah-range.character: Mix of forested ridge walking and rocky ledges with views into Pinkham Notch and toward Mount Washington.

seasonalConsiderations.summer: Expect roots and muddy sections in the woods; ledges dry quickly but can be slippery after rain.
seasonalConsiderations.winter: Ice and wind make the ledges and Wildcat ridge demanding; traction devices and poles are recommended.

twin-range.description: Long Pemigewasset Wilderness miles featuring Bondcliff’s ledge and West Bond’s sunset perch; logistics vary by season.
twin-range.extendedDescription: The Twin Range sits on the western rim of the Pemigewasset Wilderness and includes South Twin, North Twin, Galehead, Zealand and Mount Hale. Much of the range is traversed by the Appalachian Trail, with the AMC’s Galehead Hut providing a convenient base. South Twin’s summit offers some of the Whites’ grandest panoramas, while North Twin and Hale are mostly wooded. Approaches via the North Twin Trail involve multiple river crossings, and Zealand’s trail offers moderate grades. Winter conditions can make river crossings hazardous and snowshoes necessary.
twin-range.character: High-elevation ridge walks with mixed wooded and open summits, often visited on multi-peak backpacking trips.

seasonalConsiderations.summer: River crossings on the North Twin Trail can be tricky after rain; plan alternate routes if water is high.
seasonalConsiderations.winter: Deep snow and unbroken trails slow progress; carry snowshoes and prepare for cold nights if backpacking.

willey-range.description: Short, steep climbs to Tom, Field, and Willey with viewpoints that reward calm-weather days.
willey-range.extendedDescription: The Willey Range runs along the west side of Crawford Notch and features the closely spaced summits of Mount Tom, Mount Field and Mount Willey. Trailheads begin near Crawford Depot and climb steeply through mixed hardwood and conifer forests. Views are limited on Tom and Field but improve on Willey, where a small overlook reveals the Presidential Range and Crawford Notch below. Many hikers loop the three peaks in a single day. Winter brings packed snow and ice; traction and poles help negotiate the steeper sections, particularly on Willey.
willey-range.character: Short but steep forest climbs leading to ledges with views into Crawford Notch.

seasonalConsiderations.summer: Steep sections can be muddy or slick; expect limited water on ridge.
seasonalConsiderations.winter: Packed snow and icy ledges require microspikes; avoid the Willey ladders in icing conditions.

pilot-pliny-range.description: Quiet forested ridges of the Kilkenny region with Cabot and Waumbek, offering limited views and solitude.
pilot-pliny-range.extendedDescription: The Pilot–Pliny Range occupies the far northern reaches of New Hampshire’s White Mountains. Its two NH48 summits—Mount Cabot and Mount Waumbek—are connected by the Kilkenny Ridge, weaving through mixed hardwood and spruce forests. These hikes follow old logging roads and footpaths to largely wooded summits; short spurs lead to outlooks over the northern Presidentials and the White Mountain core. The range is remote and lightly traveled; road closures can add mileage in winter, and trail conditions vary with mud and snow.
pilot-pliny-range.character: Wooded ridgewalks through quiet northern forests with occasional ledge views.

seasonalConsiderations.summer: Expect muddy sections and bugs; trails are gentle but long; limited water sources.
seasonalConsiderations.winter: Road closures may extend distances; deep snow and wind drifts on Kilkenny Ridge require snowshoes.

sandwich-waterville-range.description: Osceola, Tripyramids, Passaconaway and Whiteface rise above Waterville Valley with varied trails and slides.
sandwich-waterville-range.extendedDescription: The Sandwich / Waterville Range occupies the southern White Mountains, encompassing the Tripyramids (North and Middle), Mount Tecumseh, Mount Osceola and East Osceola, and the peaks of Passaconaway and Whiteface. Trails range from the steep ledge climbs and north slide of the Tripyramids to the chimney scramble between East Osceola and Mount Osceola and the family-friendly climb up Tecumseh. Views are intermittent but rewarding from open ledges on the Tripyramids and Whiteface. Seasonal conditions vary greatly; slides become treacherous when wet or icy, and some trailheads close in winter.
sandwich-waterville-range.character: Varied terrain with open ledges, slides and wooded summits in the southern Whites near Waterville Valley.

seasonalConsiderations.summer: Check Tripoli Road status; slides and ledges can be slick after rain; heat and humidity slow progress.
seasonalConsiderations.winter: Tripoli Road and Waterville trailheads may be closed; ice and packed snow require traction; chimney section on Osceola may need bypass.

pemi-wilderness-remote-peaks.description: Remote and rugged peaks deep within the Pemigewasset Wilderness; long approaches and wilderness solitude.
pemi-wilderness-remote-peaks.extendedDescription: The Pemigewasset Wilderness group contains some of the most secluded NH48 summits: Bondcliff, Mount Bond, West Bond, Mount Carrigain, Owl’s Head, and the North and South Hancock peaks. These mountains lie deep within the Pemigewasset Wilderness and require lengthy approaches along valley trails and forested ridges. The Bondcliff ledges and Carrigain’s fire tower offer expansive views, while Owl’s Head and the Hancocks require challenging slide or bushwhack routes. Trails often cross rivers and muddy sections; weather can be unpredictable in the remote interior.
pemi-wilderness-remote-peaks.character: Remote wilderness peaks reached via long approaches, slides, and isolated ridgelines.

seasonalConsiderations.summer: Prepare for long mileage and stream crossings; black flies and humidity common.
seasonalConsiderations.winter: Approaches may be untracked; river crossings may be hazardous; early start and navigation skills essential.
